   Comments:
   pO2: No Calls Made - Not Arterial Blood
   Type:[**Last Name (un) **]
   Na:131

   Hgb:11.4
   CalcHCT:34
   Dark as well as some bright blood were seen in the stomach. A large
   clot that was found adhereing to the fundus during earlier
   endoscopy was now seen to extend from the fundus upto beyond the
   pylorus. After extensive flushing, the clot was dislodged and passed
   below into the antrum and pylorus. Subsequently a subcutaneous
   appearing blood vessel with mild oozing was noted in the fundus, likely
   a Dieulafuoy lesion.[10][1] The vessel was injected with a total of 8ml
   of 1:10,000 epinephrine. Attempts to clip the vessel failed three times
   due to mucosal sloughing. Subsequently the vessel was cauterized with a
   gold probe and hemostasis was achieved.
   Assessment and Plan
   49 y/o F with DM2, HTN,  CAD s/p CABG, admitted/in hospital for MSSA
   bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, hypotension from sepsis
   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from
   ASA/Plavix in setting of critical illness and prior hx of ulcers.
   Upper GI Bleed: active bleeding that did not clear with NG lavage. GI
   urgently consulted. Emergently establish access with Central Line ([**Location (un) **])
   and peripheral 20 G in addition to single lumen power-PICC
   -          Maintain [**Location (un) **] and power-PICC (both equivalent to > 18G)
   -          NPO
   -          Maintain active T&S
   -          IV protonix bolus, then drip
   -          Transfuse 3 units pRBCs, and 1 unit of platelets stat, then
   check post
transfusion HCT
   -          Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline
   HCT of 30
   -          Give DDAVP for uremic platelets in the setting of renal
   failure
   -          Q4H HCT
   -          Appreciate GI recommendation
   -          Plan for scope in unit
   Leukocytosis: no clear source other than foot,  known bacteremia which
   has cleared per blood cultures or diarrhea that is c. diff neg. Could
   be stress response to GI bleed
   -          Trend, add on diff
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Follow-up CXR
   -          Follow-up repeat C. diff pending
   -          Repeat Ucx, given foley catheter in place
   -          Monitor clinical exam
   MSSA Bacteremia: repeat blood cultures negative. Temp [**3-7**] to 99.5 on
   standing tylenol.
   -          Continue nafcillin (does not need renal dosing)
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Appreciate ID recommendations
   Left Charcot Foot and Cellulitis:
   -          Continue nafcillin
   -          Follow-up on final tissue cultures
   -          Monitor for improvement
   -          Appreciate podiatric surgery recommendations
   [**Last Name (un) **] d/t ATN: patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to
   hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
   -          Renally dose all meds
   -          Hold sevelamer while NPO
   -          Monitor UOP, trend Cr
   -          Keep MAPs > 60 to maintain renal perfusion
   -          Appreciate renal consult recommendations
   Hyponatremia: 130,  in setting volume depletion. Has been an issue
   throughout hospitalization and improves with volume and hydration
   -          Hydrate as above
   -          Trend Na with [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   Diarrhea: currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic
   associated with multiple negative c. diff
   -          When able to tolerate PO initiate yogurt in diet /
   probiotics
   -          Consider loperamide once GI bleed resolves and if there is
   no evidence for infection
   Cervical Disc Disease: C6-C7 disc herniation
   -          Appreciate spine consultation recommendations
   -          Will hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable
   from a Upper GI bleed perspective
   DM c/b retinopathy, neuropathy:
   -          Lantus to 20 units (half dose) QHS given NPO status
   -          Got 40 units of glargine last night, q2H fingersticks and
   may need D5 drip given NPO
   -          Continue HISS but only treat BG > 200 given currently NPO
   -          Renally dose gabapentin and hold until while patient NPO
   Pain: concern that tylenol could be masking fevers
   -          Stop tylenol for 48 hours to trend temperature curve
   -          Continue dilaudid IV for pain
   HTN:
   -          Continue to hold norvasc, lasix, lopressor, valsartan
   -          Monitor BPs
   CAD s/p CABG [**2197**]:  last intervention > 1 year ago, given acute upper
   GI bleed need to stop ASA and Plavix.
   -          Restart imdur when able
   -          Check EKG
   Diastolic CHF:
   -          Consider using lasix with blood transfusions to prevent
   fluid overload.
   HL: hold atorvastatin and fish oil while NPO
   Anemia, baseline 31: hold iron, MVI
   Vitamin D Deficiency: hold vitamin D
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2207-3-8**] 07:18 AM
   20 Gauge - [**2207-3-8**] 09:00 AM
   [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] - [**2207-3-8**] 09:26 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:
   _______________________
   [11][1] Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a
   large tortuous arteriole in the stomach wall that erodes and bleeds. It
   can cause gastric hemorrhage but is relatively uncommon. It is thought
   to cause less than 5% of all gastrointestinal bleeds in adults. It was
   named after [**Name2 (NI) 4162**] surgeon [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 98**] [**Name (NI) 11867**] Dieulafoy, who described this
   condition in his paper "Exulceratio simplex: Le
ons [**12-28**]" in 1898. It is
   also called "caliber-persistent artery" or "aneurysm" of gastric
   vessels. However, unlike most other aneurysms these are thought to be
   developmental malformations rather than degenerative changes.

   49 y/o F with DM2, HTN,  CAD s/p CABG, admitted/in hospital for MSSA
   bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, hypotension from sepsis
   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from

   Upper GI Bleed: active bleeding that did not clear with NG lavage. GI

   and peripheral 20 G in addition to single lumen power-PICC

   -          Transfuse 3 units pRBCs, and 1 unit of platelets stat, then
   check post
transfusion HCT
   -          Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline

   -          Give DDAVP for uremic platelets in the setting of renal
   failure
   -          Q4H HCT
   -          Appreciate GI recommendation
   -          Plan for scope in unit
   Leukocytosis: no clear source other than foot,  known bacteremia which
   has cleared per blood cultures or diarrhea that is c. diff neg. Could
   be stress response to GI bleed
   -          Trend, add on diff
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Follow-up CXR
   -          Follow-up repeat C. diff pending
   -          Repeat Ucx, given foley catheter in place
   -          Monitor clinical exam
   MSSA Bacteremia: repeat blood cultures negative. Temp [**3-7**] to 99.5 on
   standing tylenol.
   -          Continue nafcillin (does not need renal dosing)
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Appreciate ID recommendations

   -          Monitor for improvement

   [**Last Name (un) **] d/t ATN: patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to
   hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
   -          Renally dose all meds

   -          Appreciate renal consult recommendations
   Hyponatremia: 130,  in setting volume depletion. Has been an issue
   throughout hospitalization and improves with volume and hydration
   -          Hydrate as above
   -          Trend Na with [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   Diarrhea: currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic
   associated with multiple negative c. diff
   -          When able to tolerate PO initiate yogurt in diet /
   probiotics

   [11][1] Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a
   large tortuous arteriole in the stomach wall that erodes and bleeds. It
   can cause gastric hemorrhage but is relatively uncommon. It is thought
   to cause less than 5% of all gastrointestinal bleeds in adults. It was
   named after [**Name2 (NI) 4162**] surgeon [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 98**] [**Name (NI) 11867**] Dieulafoy, who described this
   condition in his paper "Exulceratio simplex: Le
ons [**12-28**]" in 1898. It is
   also called "caliber-persistent artery" or "aneurysm" of gastric
   vessels. However, unlike most other aneurysms these are thought to be
   developmental malformations rather than degenerative changes.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Bleeding complications:
	* Continued bleeding from the Dieulafoy's lesion in the stomach, which may lead to further blood loss and potentially life-threatening complications.
	* Risk of bleeding from other sources, such as the upper GI tract, due to the patient's history of ulcers and ASA/Plavix use.
2. Infection:
	* Risk of sepsis and organ failure due to the patient's MSSA bacteremia and underlying comorbidities.
	* Potential for further infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections, given the patient's indwelling catheter and recent antibiotic use.
3. Renal complications:
	* Acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to hypotension and MSSA bacteremia, which may lead to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease.
	* Risk of further renal impairment or failure due to ongoing hypotension and potential nephrotoxicity from medications.
4. Cardiovascular complications:
	* Risk of cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to the patient's history of CAD and recent upper GI bleed.
	* Potential for further cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac failure, given the patient's underlying cardiovascular disease.
5. Gastrointestinal complications:
	* Risk of further GI bleeding or perforation due to the patient's underlying GI disease and recent upper GI bleed.
	* Potential for malnutrition or electrolyte imbalances due to the patient's NPO status and ongoing GI bleeding.
6. Respiratory complications:
	* Risk of respiratory failure or pneumonia due to the patient's underlying respiratory disease and potential aspiration of gastric contents.
	* Potential for further respiratory complications, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), given the patient's underlying cardiovascular disease and potential for fluid overload.
7. Neurological complications:
	* Risk of seizures or stroke due to the patient's underlying neurological disease and potential for hypotension and electrolyte imbalances.
	* Potential for further neurological complications, such as encephalopathy or meningitis, given the patient's underlying infections and potential for sepsis.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent or minimize these potential complications.

   Dark as well as some bright blood were seen in the stomach. A large
   clot that was found adhereing to the fundus during earlier
   endoscopy was now seen to extend from the fundus upto beyond the
   pylorus. After extensive flushing, the clot was dislodged and passed
   below into the antrum and pylorus. Subsequently a subcutaneous
   appearing blood vessel with mild oozing was noted in the fundus, likely
   a Dieulafuoy lesion.[10][1] The vessel was injected with a total of 8ml
   of 1:10,000 epinephrine. Attempts to clip the vessel failed three times
   due to mucosal sloughing. Subsequently the vessel was cauterized with a
   gold probe and hemostasis was achieved.

   [11][1] Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a
   large tortuous arteriole in the stomach wall that erodes and bleeds. It
   can cause gastric hemorrhage but is relatively uncommon. It is thought
   to cause less than 5% of all gastrointestinal bleeds in adults. It was
   named after [**Name2 (NI) 4162**] surgeon [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 98**] [**Name (NI) 11867**] Dieulafoy, who described this
   condition in his paper "Exulceratio simplex: Le
ons [**12-28**]" in 1898. It is
   also called "caliber-persistent artery" or "aneurysm" of gastric
   vessels. However, unlike most other aneurysms these are thought to be
   developmental malformations rather than degenerative changes.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary of Progress:**

The patient has been admitted to the ICU with a history of bleeding and has undergone multiple endoscopies to manage the bleeding. The patient has been receiving blood transfusions and has been treated with medications to manage the bleeding and prevent further complications. The patient's hemoglobin levels have been increasing, but the bleeding has been ongoing, and the patient has required additional interventions to manage the bleeding.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Gastrointestinal Bleeding:** The patient has experienced significant bleeding from the stomach, which has required multiple endoscopies and interventions to manage. The bleeding has been ongoing, and the patient is at risk for further bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock, organ failure, and death.
2. **Coagulopathy:** The patient has been receiving blood transfusions and has been treated with medications to manage the bleeding. However, the patient may still be at risk for coagulopathy, which can lead to further bleeding and complications.
3. **Infection:** The patient has been intubated and has been receiving antibiotics to manage the bleeding. However, the patient is at risk for infection, particularly in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.
4. **Organ Failure:** The patient has been experiencing hypotension and has required vasopressors to manage the blood pressure. The patient is at risk for organ failure, particularly in the kidneys, liver, and lungs.
5. **Cardiovascular Complications:** The patient has been experiencing hypertension and has required vasopressors to manage the blood pressure. The patient is at risk for cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias, myocardial infarction, and cardiac arrest.
6. **Neurological Complications:** The patient has been intubated and has been receiving sedation and analgesia to manage the pain and anxiety. The patient is at risk for neurological complications, such as seizures, brain edema, and cerebral vasospasm.
7. **Nutritional Complications:** The patient has been receiving enteral nutrition and has been at risk for nutritional deficiencies, particularly in protein, calories, and electrolytes.
8. **Psychological Complications:** The patient has been experiencing stress, anxiety, and fear due to the bleeding and the ICU environment. The patient is at risk for psychological complications, such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression, and anxiety disorders.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding and coagulation status closely.
2. Continue to manage the patient's pain and anxiety with sedation and analgesia.
3. Continue to provide enteral nutrition and monitor the patient's nutritional status.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular and neurological status closely.
5. Consider consulting a gastroenterologist and a cardiologist to manage the patient's bleeding and cardiovascular complications.
6. Consider transferring the patient to a higher-level care facility if the bleeding cannot be managed in the ICU.

   [2][1] Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a
   large tortuous arteriole in the stomach wall that erodes and bleeds. It
   can cause gastric hemorrhage but is relatively uncommon. It is thought
   to cause less than 5% of all gastrointestinal bleeds in adults. It was
   named after [**Name2 (NI) 4162**] surgeon [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 98**] [**Name (NI) 11867**] Dieulafoy, who described this
   condition in his paper "Exulceratio simplex: Le
ons [**12-28**]" in 1898. It is
   also called "caliber-persistent artery" or "aneurysm" of gastric
   vessels. However, unlike most other aneurysms these are thought to be
   developmental malformations rather than degenerative changes.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a [age] year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's hemoglobin (Hb) level was 17% on admission, and he received 4 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) with a subsequent increase in Hb to 25%. The patient was scoped and found to have a large clot in the stomach, which was unable to be intervened upon. The patient was planned for repeat scope tomorrow.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 85 beats per minute (bpm), and blood pressure of 126/58 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 100%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count (WBC) of 21.9 x 10^9/L, platelet count (PLT) of 442 x 10^9/L, and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 168 mg/dL. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 20 IU/L and an alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level of 134 IU/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for congestive heart failure and allergies to sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim. The patient is receiving pantoprazole, propofol, and fentanyl infusions.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding may continue or worsen, requiring further intervention.
2. Infection: The patient's elevated WBC count and LFTs may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is slightly elevated, and the patient may require mechanical ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's congestive heart failure may worsen, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, cardiogenic shock, or cardiac arrest.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and decreased responsiveness may be related to hypoxia, sepsis, or other underlying conditions.

Based on the patient's progress note, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status closely.
2. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding, including repeat endoscopy and potential intervention.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide mechanical ventilation as needed to maintain adequate oxygenation.
4. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's underlying medical conditions, including congestive heart failure and allergies.
5. Provide supportive care, including fluid management and nutritional support, to help the patient recover from his illness.

   Dark as well as some bright blood were seen in the stomach. A large
   clot that was found adhereing to the fundus during earlier
   endoscopy was now seen to extend from the fundus upto beyond the
   pylorus. After extensive flushing, the clot was dislodged and passed
   below into the antrum and pylorus. Subsequently a subcutaneous
   appearing blood vessel with mild oozing was noted in the fundus, likely
   a Dieulafuoy lesion.[10][1] The vessel was injected with a total of 8ml
   of 1:10,000 epinephrine. Attempts to clip the vessel failed three times
   due to mucosal sloughing. Subsequently the vessel was cauterized with a
   gold probe and hemostasis was achieved.
   Assessment and Plan
   49 y/o F with DM2, HTN,  CAD s/p CABG, admitted/in hospital for MSSA
   bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, hypotension from sepsis
   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from
   ASA/Plavix in setting of critical illness and prior hx of ulcers.
   Upper GI Bleed: active bleeding that did not clear with NG lavage.
   Scope x2 yesterday showing clot in stomach the first endoscopy and then
   were able to intervene on second endoscopy with cautery (see GI note).
   Was intubated for second endoscopy and remains intubated.  Not
   adequately responding to a total of 9 PRBCs, 3 plts, and 2 FFP.
   Continues to have melena output.
   -          Maintain [**Location (un) **] and power-PICC (both equivalent to > 18G)
   -          NPO
   -          Maintain active T&S
   -          IV protonix gtt
   -          Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline
   HCT of 30
   -          Give DDAVP for uremic platelets in the setting of renal
   failure
   -          Q4H HCT
   -          Appreciate GI, surgery and IR recommendation
   Leukocytosis: no clear source other than foot,  known bacteremia which
   has cleared per blood cultures or diarrhea that is c. diff neg. Could
   be stress response to GI bleed
   -          Trend, add on diff
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Follow-up CXR
   -          Follow-up repeat C. diff pending
   -          Repeat Ucx, given foley catheter in place
   -          Monitor clinical exam
   MSSA Bacteremia: repeat blood cultures negative. Temp [**3-7**] to 99.5 on
   standing tylenol.
   -          Continue nafcillin (does not need renal dosing)
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Appreciate ID recommendations
   Left Charcot Foot and Cellulitis:
   -          Continue nafcillin
   -          Follow-up on final tissue cultures
   -          Monitor for improvement
   -          Appreciate podiatric surgery recommendations
   [**Last Name (un) **] d/t ATN: patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to
   hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
   -          Renally dose all meds
   -          Hold sevelamer while NPO
   -          Monitor UOP, trend Cr
   -          Keep MAPs > 60 to maintain renal perfusion
   -          Appreciate renal consult recommendations
   Hyponatremia: 130,  in setting volume depletion. Has been an issue
   throughout hospitalization and improves with volume and hydration
   -          Hydrate as above
   -          Trend Na with [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   Diarrhea: currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic
   associated with multiple negative c. diff
   -          When able to tolerate PO initiate yogurt in diet /
   probiotics
   -          Consider loperamide once GI bleed resolves and if there is
   no evidence for infection
   Cervical Disc Disease: C6-C7 disc herniation
   -          Appreciate spine consultation recommendations
   -          Will hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable
   from a Upper GI bleed perspective
   DM c/b retinopathy, neuropathy:
   -          Lantus to 20 units (half dose) QHS given NPO status
   -          Got 40 units of glargine last night, q2H fingersticks and
   may need D5 drip given NPO
   -          Continue HISS but only treat BG > 200 given currently NPO
   -          Renally dose gabapentin and hold until while patient NPO
   Pain: concern that tylenol could be masking fevers
   -          Stop tylenol for 48 hours to trend temperature curve
   -          Continue dilaudid IV for pain
   HTN:
   -          Continue to hold norvasc, lasix, lopressor, valsartan
   -          Monitor BPs
   CAD s/p CABG [**2197**]:  last intervention > 1 year ago, given acute upper
   GI bleed need to stop ASA and Plavix.
   -          Restart imdur when able
   -          Check EKG
   Diastolic CHF:
   -          Consider using lasix with blood transfusions to prevent
   fluid overload.
   HL: hold atorvastatin and fish oil while NPO
   Anemia, baseline 31: hold iron, MVI

   Dark as well as some bright blood were seen in the stomach. A large
   clot that was found adhereing to the fundus during earlier
   endoscopy was now seen to extend from the fundus upto beyond the
   pylorus. After extensive flushing, the clot was dislodged and passed
   below into the antrum and pylorus. Subsequently a subcutaneous
   appearing blood vessel with mild oozing was noted in the fundus, likely
   a Dieulafuoy lesion.[10][1] The vessel was injected with a total of 8ml
   of 1:10,000 epinephrine. Attempts to clip the vessel failed three times
   due to mucosal sloughing. Subsequently the vessel was cauterized with a
   gold probe and hemostasis was achieved.
   Assessment and Plan
   49 y/o F with DM2, HTN,  CAD s/p CABG, admitted/in hospital for MSSA
   bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, hypotension from sepsis
   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from
   ASA/Plavix in setting of critical illness and prior hx of ulcers.
   Upper GI Bleed: active bleeding that did not clear with NG lavage.
   Scope x2 yesterday showing clot in stomach the first endoscopy and then
   were able to intervene on second endoscopy with cautery (see GI note).
   Was intubated for second endoscopy and remains intubated.  Not
   adequately responding to a total of 9 PRBCs, 3 plts, and 2 FFP.
   Continues to have melena output.
   -          Maintain [**Location (un) **] and power-PICC (both equivalent to > 18G)
   -          NPO
   -          Maintain active T&S
   -          IV protonix gtt
   -          Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline
   HCT of 30
   -          Give DDAVP for uremic platelets in the setting of renal
   failure
   -          Q4H HCT
   -          Appreciate GI, surgery and IR recommendation
   Leukocytosis: no clear source other than foot,  known bacteremia which
   has cleared per blood cultures or diarrhea that is c. diff neg. Could
   be stress response to GI bleed
   -          Trend, add on diff
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Follow-up CXR
   -          Follow-up repeat C. diff pending
   -          Repeat Ucx, given foley catheter in place
   -          Monitor clinical exam
   MSSA Bacteremia: repeat blood cultures negative. Temp [**3-7**] to 99.5 on
   standing tylenol.
   -          Continue nafcillin (does not need renal dosing)
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Appreciate ID recommendations
   Left Charcot Foot and Cellulitis:
   -          Continue nafcillin
   -          Follow-up on final tissue cultures
   -          Monitor for improvement
   -          Appreciate podiatric surgery recommendations
   [**Last Name (un) **] d/t ATN: patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to
   hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
   -          Renally dose all meds
   -          Hold sevelamer while NPO
   -          Monitor UOP, trend Cr
   -          Keep MAPs > 60 to maintain renal perfusion
   -          Appreciate renal consult recommendations
   Hyponatremia: 130,  in setting volume depletion. Has been an issue
   throughout hospitalization and improves with volume and hydration
   -          Hydrate as above
   -          Trend Na with [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   Diarrhea: currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic
   associated with multiple negative c. diff
   -          When able to tolerate PO initiate yogurt in diet /
   probiotics
   -          Consider loperamide once GI bleed resolves and if there is
   no evidence for infection
   Cervical Disc Disease: C6-C7 disc herniation
   -          Appreciate spine consultation recommendations
   -          Will hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable
   from a Upper GI bleed perspective
   DM c/b retinopathy, neuropathy:
   -          Lantus to 20 units (half dose) QHS given NPO status
   -          Got 40 units of glargine last night, q2H fingersticks and
   may need D5 drip given NPO
   -          Continue HISS but only treat BG > 200 given currently NPO
   -          Renally dose gabapentin and hold until while patient NPO
   Pain: concern that tylenol could be masking fevers
   -          Stop tylenol for 48 hours to trend temperature curve
   -          Continue dilaudid IV for pain
   HTN:
   -          Continue to hold norvasc, lasix, lopressor, valsartan
   -          Monitor BPs
   CAD s/p CABG [**2197**]:  last intervention > 1 year ago, given acute upper
   GI bleed need to stop ASA and Plavix.
   -          Restart imdur when able
   -          Check EKG
   Diastolic CHF:
   -          Consider using lasix with blood transfusions to prevent
   fluid overload.
   HL: hold atorvastatin and fish oil while NPO
   Anemia, baseline 31: hold iron, MVI
   Vitamin D Deficiency: hold vitamin D

   [11][1] Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a
   large tortuous arteriole in the stomach wall that erodes and bleeds. It
   can cause gastric hemorrhage but is relatively uncommon. It is thought
   to cause less than 5% of all gastrointestinal bleeds in adults. It was
   named after [**Name2 (NI) 4162**] surgeon [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 98**] [**Name (NI) 11867**] Dieulafoy, who described this
   condition in his paper "Exulceratio simplex: Le
ons [**12-28**]" in 1898. It is
   also called "caliber-persistent artery" or "aneurysm" of gastric
   vessels. However, unlike most other aneurysms these are thought to be
   developmental malformations rather than degenerative changes.

Summary:

The patient is a 49-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney disease. She was admitted to the hospital for MSSA bacteremia, Charcot foot, and upper gastrointestinal bleed. The patient underwent two endoscopies, which showed a large clot in the stomach, and was intubated for the second endoscopy. She received 9 units of packed red blood cells, 3 units of platelets, and 2 units of fresh frozen plasma. Despite this, her hemoglobin level remained low, and she was transfused with additional units of blood products.

The patient's laboratory results showed:

* Hemoglobin: 7.1 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 17.6%
* Platelet count: 442,000/mm³
* White blood cell count: 21.9 x 10³/mm³
* Blood urea nitrogen: 168 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 3.7 mg/dL
* Glucose: 154 mg/dL
* Calcium: 7.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 6.4 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* MSSA bacteremia
* Charcot foot
* Upper gastrointestinal bleed
* Diabetes mellitus type 2
* Hypertension
* Coronary artery disease
* Chronic kidney disease

The patient's medications include:

* Nafcillin
* Lasix
* Protonix
* Midazolam
* Fentanyl
* Propofol
* Erythromycin

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, which can lead to sepsis if not properly treated.
2. Upper gastrointestinal bleed: The patient has an ongoing upper gastrointestinal bleed, which can lead to further bleeding, hypovolemic shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Renal failure: The patient has chronic kidney disease and is at risk for acute kidney injury due to the use of nephrotoxic medications and the presence of sepsis.
4. Hypovolemic shock: The patient has a significant amount of blood loss due to the upper gastrointestinal bleed, which can lead to hypovolemic shock if not properly treated.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of respiratory failure.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and is at risk for cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, and cardiac failure.
7. Infection: The patient has MSSA bacteremia, which can lead to further infections if not properly treated.
8. Bleeding: The patient has a history of bleeding, which can lead to further bleeding complications if not properly managed.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's hemodynamic status and adjust treatment as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's MSSA bacteremia with antibiotics.
3. Continue to manage the patient's upper gastrointestinal bleed with endoscopic therapy and blood transfusions.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust treatment as needed.
6. Consider consulting with a nephrologist and a cardiologist to optimize the patient's care.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust treatment as needed.
8. Consider consulting with a pulmonologist to optimize the patient's respiratory care.

   Dark as well as some bright blood were seen in the stomach. A large
   clot that was found adhereing to the fundus during earlier
   endoscopy was now seen to extend from the fundus upto beyond the
   pylorus. After extensive flushing, the clot was dislodged and passed
   below into the antrum and pylorus. Subsequently a subcutaneous
   appearing blood vessel with mild oozing was noted in the fundus, likely
   a Dieulafuoy lesion.[10][1] The vessel was injected with a total of 8ml
   of 1:10,000 epinephrine. Attempts to clip the vessel failed three times
   due to mucosal sloughing. Subsequently the vessel was cauterized with a
   gold probe and hemostasis was achieved.

Based on the provided progress note, I have summarized the patient's health status and potential medical complications as follows:

**Patient's Health Status:**

* The patient is a 49-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and Charcot foot infected with methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA).
* She was admitted to the hospital for MSSA bacteremia, Charcot foot infected with MSSA, and hypotension from sepsis.
* She has a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) and has been experiencing melena output.
* She is currently intubated and receiving oxygen therapy.
* Her laboratory results show leukocytosis, hyponatremia, and elevated creatinine levels, indicating acute kidney injury (ATN).

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding (UGIB):** The patient's UGIB is likely caused by her history of ulcers and ASA/Plavix use. The bleeding has not cleared with nasogastric lavage, and she requires ongoing transfusions.
2. **Acute Kidney Injury (ATN):** The patient's ATN is likely caused by hypotension in the setting of MSSA bacteremia. She requires close monitoring of her renal function and fluid status.
3. **Diabetes Mellitus Type 2:** The patient's diabetes is poorly controlled, and she requires ongoing management of her blood glucose levels.
4. **Hypertension:** The patient's hypertension is likely contributing to her renal impairment and requires ongoing management.
5. **Coronary Artery Disease (CAD):** The patient's CAD is a significant risk factor for her UGIB and requires ongoing management.
6. **Charcot Foot:** The patient's Charcot foot is infected with MSSA and requires ongoing management and monitoring.
7. **Methicillin-Susceptible Staphylococcus Aureus (MSSA) Bacteremia:** The patient's MSSA bacteremia is likely causing her UGIB and ATN and requires ongoing treatment with antibiotics.
8. **Leukocytosis:** The patient's leukocytosis may be caused by her underlying infections or inflammatory response and requires ongoing monitoring.
9. **Hyponatremia:** The patient's hyponatremia may be caused by her volume depletion and requires ongoing management with fluids and electrolytes.
10. **Cervical Disc Disease:** The patient's cervical disc disease may be contributing to her spinal pain and requires ongoing management and monitoring.

In conclusion, the patient is at high risk for further complications due to her underlying medical conditions, including UGIB, ATN, diabetes, hypertension, CAD, Charcot foot, MSSA bacteremia, leukocytosis, hyponatremia, and cervical disc disease. Close monitoring and management of these conditions are essential to prevent further complications and ensure the patient's overall well-being.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old woman with a complex medical condition, including:

1. Gastrointestinal bleed due to a Dieulafoy lesion, with ongoing melena.
2. Blood loss anemia, requiring 9 units of packed red blood cells.
3. Respiratory failure, requiring invasive ventilation.
4. Acute kidney injury (AKI) with oliguria, requiring nephrotoxic medication hold.
5. Leukocytosis, with a white blood cell count of 24.9 K/uL.
6. Uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM2).
7. Charcot foot with a 6 cm linear incision.
8. Coronary artery disease (CAD) with ischemic heart disease.
9. Hypertension, benign.
10. Hyponatremia (low sodium) with hyposmolality.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Aspiration pneumonia due to the patient's inability to protect her airway.
2. Sepsis and septic shock due to the GI bleed and possible bacterial contamination.
3. Further bleeding complications, including bleeding from the Dieulafoy lesion or other sources.
4. Respiratory failure and ventilator-associated complications, such as ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI).
5. Acute kidney injury (AKI) progressing to chronic kidney disease (CKD).
6. Worsening of the patient's diabetes mellitus, potentially leading to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) or hyperglycemic hyperosmolar nonketotic syndrome (HHNS).
7. Infection and cellulitis at the site of the Charcot foot incision.
8. Cardiovascular complications, including acute myocardial infarction (AMI) or cardiac arrhythmias.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Rescope and endoscopy to assess the Dieulafoy lesion.
2. Conservative management of the patient's airway, with close monitoring for signs of respiratory failure.
3. Holding nephrotoxic medications and monitoring the patient's kidney function.
4. Close monitoring of the patient's blood glucose levels and adjusting insulin therapy as needed.
5. Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
6. Frequent assessments of the patient's skin integrity and wound care at the site of the Charcot foot incision.

The patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and aggressive management are necessary to prevent further complications and improve her chances of recovery.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-year-old woman with a history of type II diabetes, Charcot foot, and coronary artery disease. She is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to gastrointestinal bleeding, blood loss anemia, and respiratory failure. The patient had a difficult intubation and was taken to the operating room for fiberoptic intubation and endoscopy, where a Dieulafoy lesion was found. She has received 9 units of packed red blood cells and is being managed with pantoprazole, midazolam, fentanyl, and lasix.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.5°C (99.5°F)
* Heart rate: 85 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 126/58 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 12 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient is being monitored for cardiac dysfunction, and her blood pressure is being carefully managed.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 7.1 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 21.9 x 10^9/L
* Platelet count: 442 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 3.7 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 168 mg/dL
* Glucose: 181 mg/dL

The patient's medical complications include:

* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Blood loss anemia
* Respiratory failure
* Leukocytosis
* Acute renal failure
* Impaired skin integrity
* Cellulitis
* Uncontrolled type II diabetes
* Coronary artery disease
* Hyponatremia
* Hypertension

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Aspiration pneumonia due to the patient's inability to protect her airway
* Sepsis due to the patient's bacteremia and leukocytosis
* Acute kidney injury due to the patient's acute renal failure
* Wound infection due to the patient's impaired skin integrity and cellulitis
* Cardiovascular complications due to the patient's coronary artery disease and hypertension
* Hyperglycemia due to the patient's uncontrolled type II diabetes
* Respiratory failure due to the patient's chronic respiratory disease.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 49-year-old female with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and a history of charcot foot. She was admitted to the hospital with methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia and charcot foot infection, and subsequently developed an upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* She is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.
* Her hemoglobin (Hb) levels have been increasing, with a current level of 28.6 g/dL, and her hematocrit (Hct) levels have been trending upwards, with a current level of 30.0%.
* She has been receiving blood transfusions to maintain a Hct level above 25%.
* She has a history of coronary artery disease and is at risk for cardiovascular complications.
* She has a left charcot foot and cellulitis, which is being treated with nafcillin.
* She has a history of upper GI bleeding, which has been managed with endoscopy and cautery.

   Assessment and Plan
   49 y/o F with DM2, HTN,  CAD s/p CABG, admitted/in hospital for MSSA
   bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, hypotension from sepsis
   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from
   ASA/Plavix in setting of critical illness and prior hx of ulcers.
   Upper GI Bleed: active bleeding that did not clear with NG lavage.
   Scope x2 Sat showing clot in stomach the first endoscopy and then were
   able to intervene on second endoscopy with cautery (see GI note).  Was
   intubated for second endoscopy and remains intubated.  Not adequately
   responding to a total of 9 PRBCs, 3 plts, and 2 FFP.  Continues to have
   melena output.
   -          Maintain [**Location (un) **] and power-PICC (both equivalent to > 18G)
   -          NPO
   -          Maintain active T&S
   -          IV protonix gtt
   -          Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline
   HCT of 30
   -          Give DDAVP for uremic platelets in the setting of renal
   failure
   -          Q4H HCT
   -          Appreciate GI, surgery and IR recommendation
   Leukocytosis: no clear source other than foot,  known bacteremia which
   has cleared per blood cultures or diarrhea that is c. diff neg. Could
   be stress response to GI bleed
   -          Trend, add on diff
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Follow-up CXR
   -          Follow-up repeat C. diff pending
   -          Repeat Ucx, given foley catheter in place
   -          Monitor clinical exam
   MSSA Bacteremia: repeat blood cultures negative. Temp [**3-7**] to 99.5 on
   standing tylenol.
   -          Continue nafcillin (does not need renal dosing)
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Appreciate ID recommendations
   Left Charcot Foot and Cellulitis:
   -          Continue nafcillin
   -          Follow-up on final tissue cultures
   -          Monitor for improvement
   -          Appreciate podiatric surgery recommendations
   [**Last Name (un) **] d/t ATN: patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to
   hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
   -          Renally dose all meds
   -          Hold sevelamer while NPO
   -          Monitor UOP, trend Cr
   -          Keep MAPs > 60 to maintain renal perfusion
   -          Appreciate renal consult recommendations
   Hyponatremia: 130,  in setting volume depletion. Has been an issue
   throughout hospitalization and improves with volume and hydration
   -          Hydrate as above
   -          Trend Na with [**Hospital1 **] lytes
   Diarrhea: currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic
   associated with multiple negative c. diff
   -          When able to tolerate PO initiate yogurt in diet /
   probiotics
   -          Consider loperamide once GI bleed resolves and if there is
   no evidence for infection
   Cervical Disc Disease: C6-C7 disc herniation
   -          Appreciate spine consultation recommendations
   -          Will hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable
   from a Upper GI bleed perspective
   DM c/b retinopathy, neuropathy:
   -          Lantus to 20 units (half dose) QHS given NPO status
   -          Got 40 units of glargine last night, q2H fingersticks and
   may need D5 drip given NPO
   -          Continue HISS but only treat BG > 200 given currently NPO
   -          Renally dose gabapentin and hold until while patient NPO
   Pain: concern that tylenol could be masking fevers
   -          Stop tylenol for 48 hours to trend temperature curve
   -          Continue dilaudid IV for pain
   HTN:
   -          Continue to hold norvasc, lasix, lopressor, valsartan
   -          Monitor BPs
   CAD s/p CABG [**2197**]:  last intervention > 1 year ago, given acute upper
   GI bleed need to stop ASA and Plavix.
   -          Restart imdur when able
   -          Check EKG
   Diastolic CHF:
   -          Consider using lasix with blood transfusions to prevent
   fluid overload.
   HL: hold atorvastatin and fish oil while NPO
   Anemia, baseline 31: hold iron, MVI
   Vitamin D Deficiency: hold vitamin D
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:

The patient is a 49-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney disease. She was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, and hypotension from sepsis. She underwent endoscopy and was intubated for the procedure. Despite receiving multiple blood transfusions, her hemoglobin level remains low, and she continues to have melena output.

The patient's condition is complicated by several factors, including:

1. Upper GI bleed: The patient has an active bleeding episode that did not respond to non-gastrointestinal (NG) lavage. She underwent endoscopy and was able to intervene with cautery, but the bleeding persisted.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient has an elevated white blood cell count, which may be due to a stress response to the GI bleed or an underlying infection.
3. MSSA bacteremia: The patient has cleared the bacteremia, but repeat blood cultures are pending.
4. Charcot foot and cellulitis: The patient has a left charcot foot and cellulitis, which are being treated with antibiotics.
5. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN): The patient has developed ATN, which is attributed to hypotension in the setting of MSSA bacteremia.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient has a low sodium level, which may be due to volume depletion.
7. Diarrhea: The patient has diarrhea, which may be related to antibiotic use or an underlying infection.
8. Cervical disc disease: The patient has a C6-C7 disc herniation, which is being managed conservatively.
9. Diabetes: The patient has diabetes, which is being managed with insulin and other medications.
10. Hypertension: The patient has hypertension, which is being managed with medication.

Potential medical complications:

1. Bleeding complications: The patient's ongoing bleeding may lead to further complications, such as hypovolemic shock or bleeding into vital organs.
2. Infection: The patient's MSSA bacteremia may lead to further infections, such as pneumonia or septicemia.
3. Renal failure: The patient's ATN may lead to further kidney damage or failure.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing bleeding may lead to respiratory failure or pneumonia.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and hypertension may lead to further cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's cervical disc disease may lead to further neurological complications, such as spinal cord compression or radiculopathy.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's ongoing bleeding may lead to further gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation or obstruction.

Based on the patient's progress note, the patient is a 47-year-old woman with type II diabetes, Charcot foot, and multiple comorbidities, admitted to the ICU with a GI bleed and blood loss anemia. She has undergone 13 units of packed red blood cell transfusions and is currently receiving 8 mg/hour of pantoprazole and 40 mcg/kg/min of propofol.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 83 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 128/57 mmHg. She is mechanically ventilated with a FiO2 of 40% and a respiratory rate of 10 inspirations per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show a hemoglobin level of 9.6 g/dL, white blood cell count of 24.9 K/uL, and platelet count of 53 K/uL. Her creatinine level is 3.3 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen level is 129 mg/dL. Her lactate level is 0.9 mmol/L, and her D-dimer level is 1862 ng/mL.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG, AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
* GASTROINTESTINAL BLEED, UPPER (MELENA, GI BLEED, GIB)
* BACTEREMIA
* LEUKOCYTOSIS
* RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
* IMPAIRED SKIN INTEGRITY
* CELLULITIS
* DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II (uncontrolled)
* DIARRHEA
* CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
* HYPONATREMIA (LOW SODIUM, HYPOSMOLALITY)
* HYPERTENSION, BENIGN
* ANEMIA, ACUTE, SECONDARY TO BLOOD LOSS (HEMORRHAGE, BLEEDING)

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure due to mechanical ventilation and potential respiratory acidosis
* Sepsis and organ failure due to bacteremia and leukocytosis
* Acute kidney injury (AKI) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to hypovolemia and nephrotoxic medications
* Skin and soft tissue infections due to impaired skin integrity and cellulitis
* Cardiovascular complications due to coronary artery disease and hypertension
* Neurological complications due to diabetes and potential hypoglycemia
* Gastrointestinal complications due to upper GI bleed and potential aspiration

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor her vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status, and to adjust her treatment plan accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-year-old woman with a history of type II diabetes, Charcot foot, and coronary artery disease, admitted to the MICU with a GI bleed and blood loss anemia. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 128/57 mmHg. She has received 13 units of packed red blood cells and is expected to undergo an EGD today.

The patient has a number of medical complications, including:

1. GI bleed: Dieulafoy lesion by endoscopy, with ongoing melena.
2. Respiratory failure: Remain intubated for endoscopy, with a plan to reassess readiness for extubation once the bleeding issue is resolved.
3. Leukocytosis: WBC down slightly today.
4. Acute renal failure (ARF)/Acute tubular necrosis (ATN): Holding nephrotoxic meds, with plans to trend.
5. Impaired skin integrity: Cellulitis in the left Charcot foot with a 6 cm linear incision.
6. Diabetes mellitus, type II: Uncontrolled.
7. Hypertension, benign.
8. Anemia, acute, secondary to blood loss.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Continued bleeding from the GI tract, potentially leading to hypovolemic shock.
2. Respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or ventilator-associated lung injury, due to prolonged intubation.
3. Acute kidney injury or worsening of ARF, potentially leading to the need for renal replacement therapy.
4. Sepsis or septic shock, potentially related to the cellulitis in the left Charcot foot.
5. Worsening of the patient's anemia, potentially leading to further blood transfusions.
6. Complications related to the patient's uncontrolled diabetes, such as hyperglycemia or ketoacidosis.
7. Cardiovascular complications, such as myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias, potentially related to the patient's coronary artery disease.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and the potential for complications, close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat any adverse events that may arise.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with a chief complaint of GI bleed and blood loss anemia. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient has a history of congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, and type II diabetes, which are uncontrolled.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 83 bpm, and blood pressure of 128/57 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 10 inspirations per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a total fluid balance of 5,298 mL, with an input of 2,647 mL and an output of 2,478 mL.

The patient's laboratory results show anemia with a hemoglobin level of 9.6 g/dL, leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 24.9 K/uL, and thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 53 K/uL. The patient's liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase level of 134 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase level of 8-14 IU/L. The patient's kidney function is impaired, with a creatinine level of 3.3 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen level of 129 mg/dL.

The patient's assessment and plan include the following potential medical complications:

1. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient is intubated and at risk for aspiration due to the inability to protect the airway.
2. Gastrointestinal bleed: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleed and is at risk for further bleeding due to the presence of an upper gastrointestinal bleed.
3. Bacteremia: The patient has a history of bacteremia and is at risk for further infection due to the presence of a central line.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient has a white blood cell count of 24.9 K/uL, which is elevated and may indicate an underlying infection or inflammation.
5. Acute renal failure: The patient's kidney function is impaired, and the patient is at risk for further kidney damage due to the presence of acute kidney injury.
6. Impaired skin integrity: The patient has a history of cellulitis and is at risk for further skin breakdown due to the presence of a wound.
7. Diabetes mellitus: The patient has uncontrolled type II diabetes and is at risk for further complications due to hyperglycemia.
8. Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension and is at risk for further complications due to uncontrolled blood pressure.
9. Anemia: The patient has anemia due to blood loss, and the patient is at risk for further anemia due to ongoing bleeding.

In conclusion, the patient is critically ill and at risk for a variety of potential medical complications. The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these complications.

Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 83 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 128/57 mmHg. Her respiratory status is also stable, with a respiratory rate of 10 inspirations per minute and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. Her laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 24.9 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.6 g/dL, and platelet count of 53 K/uL. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slight elevation in lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and a decrease in albumin.

Potential medical complications:

1. Aspiration: The patient's inability to protect her airway increases the risk of aspiration, which can lead to respiratory complications.
2. Bacteremia: The patient has a diagnosis of MSSA bacteremia, which requires continued antibiotic treatment to prevent further complications.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may indicate an ongoing inflammatory response, which can lead to further complications if not managed appropriately.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure (ARF) requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration.
5. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's Charcot foot with a 6 cm linear incision that probes deep into tissue/ligaments/bone increases the risk of infection and further complications.
6. Cellulitis: The patient's Charcot foot also increases the risk of cellulitis, which can lead to further complications if not managed appropriately.
7. Diabetic ketoacidosis: The patient's uncontrolled type II diabetes increases the risk of diabetic ketoacidosis, which can lead to further complications if not managed appropriately.
8. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure of 128/57 mmHg may indicate hypotension, which can lead to further complications if not managed appropriately.
9. Hypoxemia: The patient's respiratory failure and congested chest X-ray (CXR) increase the risk of hypoxemia, which can lead to further complications if not managed appropriately.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from

   -          Monitor for improvement

   -          Vascular recommends noncontrast CT of LLE
   -          Surgery Recs: [**Hospital1 **] betadine packing, DSD, ace daily
   -          Plan for further debridement once medically stable

   associated with multiple negative c. diff
   -          When able to tolerate PO initiate yogurt in diet /
   probiotics
   -          Consider loperamide once GI bleed resolves and if there is
   no evidence for infection
   Cervical Disc Disease: C6-C7 disc herniation
   -          Appreciate spine consultation recommendations
   -          Will hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable
   from a Upper GI bleed perspective
   DM c/b retinopathy, neuropathy:
   -          Lantus to 20 units (half dose) QHS given NPO status
   -          Continue HISS but only treat BG > 200 given currently NPO
   -          Renally dose gabapentin and hold until while patient NPO

   CAD s/p CABG [**2197**]:  last intervention > 1 year ago, given acute upper
   GI bleed need to stop ASA and Plavix.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 49-year-old female with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease (CAD) with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), and a recent upper gastrointestinal bleed. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation for respiratory support.

The patient has a number of potential medical complications that can arise, including:

1. Sepsis: The patient has a history of MSSA bacteremia, which has cleared per blood cultures, but she remains at risk for sepsis given her underlying medical conditions.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently stable, but she remains at risk for respiratory failure given her underlying lung disease and the need for mechanical ventilation.
3. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level has peaked at 4.3, and she is at risk for renal failure given her underlying kidney disease and the need for diuretics.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is currently stable, but she remains at risk for hypotension given her underlying medical conditions and the need for vasopressors.
5. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, which has not yet fully resolved, and she remains at risk for further bleeding given her underlying medical conditions.
6. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis, which may be due to a variety of factors, including the underlying infection, stress response to the upper gastrointestinal bleed, or other underlying medical conditions.
7. Charcot foot and cellulitis: The patient has a history of Charcot foot and cellulitis, which may lead to further complications, including osteomyelitis and amputation.
8. Hypocalcemia: The patient has hypocalcemia, which may be due to a variety of factors, including the underlying medical conditions and the need for diuretics.
9. Vitamin D deficiency: The patient has a vitamin D deficiency, which may lead to further complications, including osteoporosis and increased risk of fractures.
10. Pain: The patient is experiencing pain, which may be due to a variety of factors, including the underlying medical conditions and the need for mechanical ventilation.

In terms of the patient's current medications, she is receiving a number of medications, including:

1. Vancomycin: The patient is receiving vancomycin for the treatment of MSSA bacteremia.
2. Nafcillin: The patient is no longer receiving nafcillin, which was previously prescribed for the treatment of MSSA bacteremia.
3. Propofol: The patient is receiving propofol for sedation and pain management.
4. Furosemide: The patient is receiving furosemide for the treatment of heart failure and hypertension.
5. Lantus: The patient is receiving Lantus for the treatment of diabetes mellitus type 2.
6. Gabapentin: The patient is receiving gabapentin for the treatment of neuropathic pain.
7. Dilaudid: The patient is receiving dilaudid for pain management.
8. Imdur: The patient is not currently receiving imdur, which was previously prescribed for the treatment of CAD.
9. Atorvastatin: The patient is not currently receiving atorvastatin, which was previously prescribed for the treatment of hyperlipidemia.
10. Fish oil: The patient is not currently receiving fish oil, which was previously prescribed for the treatment of hyperlipidemia.

In terms of the patient's laboratory results, her creatinine level has peaked at 4.3, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 65 mg/dL. Her calcium level is 8.0 mg/dL, and her phosphorus level is 6.9 mg/dL. Her complete blood count (CBC) shows a white blood cell count of 16.3, a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL, and a platelet count of 353.

Overall, the patient is at risk for a number of potential complications, including sepsis, respiratory failure, renal failure, hypotension, upper gastrointestinal bleeding, leukocytosis, Charcot foot and cellulitis, hypocalcemia, vitamin D deficiency, and pain.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 49-year-old female with a complex medical history, including diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease (CAD) with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), and a current upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation in the intensive care unit (ICU).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic instability with a heart rate of 77 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 137/57 mmHg.
* Respiratory compromise with a respiratory rate of 9 inspirations per minute and a partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) of 100%.
* Renal impairment with a creatinine level of 2.6 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 65 mg/dL.
* Leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 16.3 x 10^9/L and a neutrophil count of 89.0%.
* Hyperglycemia with a blood glucose level of 129 mg/dL.
* Hyponatremia with a sodium level of 136 mmol/L.
* Diarrhea and melena.
* Cervical disc disease with a C6-C7 disc herniation.

The patient is receiving the following medications:

* Vancomycin for MSSA bacteremia.
* Propofol for sedation.
* Protonix for stress ulcer prophylaxis.
* Lantus for diabetes management.
* Dilaudid for pain management.
* Imdur for CAD.

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* Complete blood count (CBC) with a white blood cell count of 16.3 x 10^9/L and a neutrophil count of 89.0%.
* Blood chemistry panel with a creatinine level of 2.6 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 65 mg/dL.
* Electrolyte panel with a sodium level of 136 mmol/L.
* Blood glucose level of 129 mg/dL.
* Complete metabolic panel (CMP) with a lactate level of 0.9 mmol/L.

The patient's imaging studies are as follows:

* Non-contrast computed tomography (CT) scan of the left lower extremity (LLE) with findings consistent with Charcot arthropathy and superimposed osteomyelitis of the mid foot with a large post-surgical soft tissue defect noted medially.
* Chest X-ray with no acute findings.

The patient's plan of care is as follows:

* Maintain intubation and mechanical ventilation.
* Continue vancomycin for MSSA bacteremia.
* Repeat blood cultures.
* Monitor for improvement in LLE cellulitis.
* Consider further debridement once medically stable.
* Hold ASA and Plavix due to acute upper GI bleed.
* Restart imdur when able.
* Check EKG.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

* Sepsis with multi-organ dysfunction.
* Respiratory failure with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* Renal failure with acute kidney injury (AKI).
* Hepatic failure with coagulopathy.
* Cardiovascular complications such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
* Gastrointestinal complications such as bleeding or perforation.
* Neurological complications such as stroke or seizures.
* Infections such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections (UTIs), or central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs).

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 68-inch, 133.4 kg individual with a medical history of congestive heart failure, who has been admitted to the ICU with a stable clot in the leg. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.2°C, heart rate of 77 bpm, and blood pressure of 137/57 mmHg. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and has a patent foramen ovale. The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 16.3, hemoglobin of 28.6 g/dL, and platelet count of 353 K/uL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but there is a risk of respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying medical conditions and the need for mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has a history of congestive heart failure, and there is a risk of cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest, due to the patient's underlying medical conditions and the need for mechanical ventilation.
3. Infection: The patient has a stable clot in the leg, and there is a risk of infection due to the presence of a foreign body.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Renal failure: The patient's laboratory results show a creatinine level of 2.6 mg/dL, which may indicate a risk of renal failure.
6. Metabolic complications: The patient's laboratory results show a glucose level of 129 mg/dL, which may indicate a risk of metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's laboratory results show a low albumin level of 1.8 g/dL, which may indicate a risk of nutritional deficiencies.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of congestive heart failure, and there is a risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea, due to the patient's underlying medical conditions.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential medical complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 47-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes, Charcot foot, and a history of gastrointestinal bleed, acute anemia, and respiratory failure. She is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with ongoing GI bleeding, blood loss anemia, and respiratory failure. Her hemoglobin concentration has remained stable for 30 hours since receiving two units of packed red blood cells. The patient has a history of allergies to sulfamethoxazole/trimethoprim and congestive heart failure.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.5°C (99.5°F)
* Heart rate: 78 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 143/63 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 11 breaths per minute (bpm)
* SpO2: 100%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus rhythm

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and has a tracheostomy tube in place. She is also receiving propofol and other medications as per the ICU team's note.

Laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.0 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 16.3 K/uL
* Platelet count: 353 K/uL
* Creatinine: 2.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 19 mg/dL
* Glucose: 129 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 6.9 mg/dL
* Albumin: 1.8 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L
* D-dimer: 1862 ng/mL
* Fibrinogen: 718 mg/dL
* Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): 209 IU/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Gastrointestinal bleed
* Bacteremia
* Leukocytosis
* Acute renal failure
* Impaired skin integrity
* Cellulitis
* Diabetes mellitus type 2
* Coronary artery disease
* Hyponatremia
* Hypertension
* Anemia, acute, secondary to blood loss

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Aspiration pneumonia due to the patient's inability to protect her airway
* Further bleeding from the gastrointestinal tract
* Worsening of acute renal failure
* Development of sepsis or septic shock
* Progression of cellulitis or skin infection
* Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia due to uncontrolled diabetes
* Cardiac complications due to coronary artery disease
* Electrolyte imbalances due to ongoing bleeding and fluid management.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 49-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, coronary artery disease, and a recent CABG. She was admitted to the hospital for MSSA bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, and upper GI bleed. The patient has been intubated since the second endoscopy and remains intubated.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 84 bpm, and blood pressure of 138/52 mmHg. Her respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 98% and a respiratory rate of 11 breaths per minute. The patient has a central line, PICC line, and is receiving IV antibiotics and proton pump inhibitors.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 14.6-14.9 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 26.7-28.5%
* Platelet count: 118-130 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 2.1-2.3 mg/dL
* Glucose: 58-65 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: within normal range
* Blood cultures: negative for MSSA bacteremia

The patient's medical conditions include:

* MSSA bacteremia: cleared per blood cultures
* Charcot foot and cellulitis: treated with vancomycin and awaiting final tissue cultures
* Left charcot foot and cellulitis: non-contrast CT of LLE showed no obvious fluid collection
* Hypertension: reasonably well-controlled
* Hyponatremia: resolved
* Diarrhea: likely antibiotic-associated
* Cervical disc disease: C6-C7 disc herniation
* DM with retinopathy and neuropathy: treated with lantus and gabapentin
* CAD s/p CABG: last intervention > 1 year ago
* HL: hold atorvastatin and fish oil while NPO
* Vitamin D deficiency: hold vitamin D

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Respiratory failure: the patient is intubated and on pressure support, and there is concern for laryngeal edema
* Renal failure: the patient has a history of hypertension and CAD, and there is concern for ATN
* Sepsis: the patient has a history of MSSA bacteremia and charcot foot infected with MSSA
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: the patient has an active upper GI bleed and is at risk for further bleeding
* Diabetic ketoacidosis: the patient has a history of diabetes mellitus type 2 and is NPO
* Hypotension: the patient has a history of hypertension and CAD, and there is concern for hypotension

Based on the patient's condition, I recommend the following:

* Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results
* Continue to treat the patient's medical conditions, including MSSA bacteremia, charcot foot and cellulitis, and hypertension
* Consider extubating the patient once stable
* Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medications as necessary
* Consider restarting ASA and Plavix once the patient is stable
* Monitor the patient's glucose levels and adjust insulin therapy as necessary
* Consider restarting vitamin D once the patient is stable
* Monitor the patient's pain levels and adjust pain medication as necessary
* Consider restarting atorvastatin and fish oil once the patient is stable

   Assessment and Plan
   49 y/o F with DM2, HTN,  CAD s/p CABG, admitted/in hospital for MSSA
   bacteremia, charcot foot infected with MSSA, hypotension from sepsis
   with [**Hospital **] transferred from medical [**Hospital1 **] with upper GI bleed likely from
   ASA/Plavix in setting of critical illness and prior hx of ulcers.
   # Upper GI Bleed: active bleeding that did not clear with NG lavage.
   Scope x2 Sat showing clot in stomach the first endoscopy and then were
   able to intervene on second endoscopy with cautery (see GI note).  Was
   intubated for second endoscopy and remains intubated. 3^rd scope
   Tuesday showing clot. Hct has now been stable for the last 24 hours.
   -          Maintain [**Location (un) **] and power-PICC (both equivalent to > 18G)
   -          NPO
   -          Maintain active T&S
   -          IV protonix gtt
   -          Transfuse to HCT > 25 given coronary history and baseline
   HCT of 30 or if drop >3
   -          Continue Q4H HCT
   # Respiratory Status/Diastolic CHF: Currently doing well intubated on
   pressure support. Difficult intubation with concern for laryngeal
   edema. Has reassuring cuff leak.
   -          Keep even today
 if stable bleed, consider diuresis
   -          plan to extubate tomorrow
   -          continue propofol gtt
   # Leukocytosis: no clear source other than foot, known bacteremia which
   has cleared per blood cultures or diarrhea that is c. diff neg. Could
   be stress response to GI bleed.
   -          Trend WBC
   -          F/U blood cultures
   -          Follow-up CXR
   -          C. Diff has been negative
   -          Monitor clinical exam for spread of erythema over LLE
   # MSSA Bacteremia: repeat blood cultures negative. Temp [**3-7**] to 99.5 on
   standing tylenol.
   -          Vancomycin (stopped nafcillin 3/16 per ID)
   -          Repeat blood cultures
   -          Appreciate ID recommendations
   # Left Charcot Foot and Cellulitis: followed by podiatry/vascular
   surgery. Non-Contrast CT of LLE:
   -          Continue vancomycin
   -          Follow-up on final tissue cultures
   -          Monitor for improvement
   -          Appreciate podiatric surgery recommendations
   -          Vascular recommends noncontrast CT of LLE
   -          Surgery Recs: [**Hospital1 **] betadine packing, DSD, ace daily
   -          Plan for further debridement once medically stable
   # [**Last Name (un) **] d/t ATN: patient without known CKD at baseline. ATN attributed to
   hypotension in setting of MSSA bacteremia. Peak Cr 4.3.
   -          Renally dose all meds
   -          Hold sevelamer while NPO
   -          Monitor UOP, trend Cr
   -          Keep MAPs > 60 to maintain renal perfusion
   -          Appreciate renal consult recommendations
   # HTN: reasonably well controlled at present
   -          Diurese today as above
   -          Continue to hold norvasc, lopressor, valsartan in setting of
   GIB
   -          Monitor BPs
   Hyponatremia: Resolved. Initially 130 in setting volume depletion. Has
   been an issue throughout hospitalization and improves with volume and
   hydration.  Na is 136 this morning.
   Diarrhea: currently in setting of melena, but prior likely antibiotic
   associated with multiple negative c. diff
   -          When able to tolerate PO initiate yogurt in diet /
   probiotics
   -          Consider loperamide once GI bleed resolves and if there is
   no evidence for infection
   Cervical Disc Disease: C6-C7 disc herniation
   -          Appreciate spine consultation recommendations
   -          Will hold on CT C spine w/o contrast until patient stable
   from a Upper GI bleed perspective
   DM c/b retinopathy, neuropathy:
   -          Lantus to 20 units (half dose) QHS given NPO status
   -          Continue HISS but only treat BG > 200 given currently NPO
   -          Renally dose gabapentin and hold until while patient NPO
   Pain: concern that tylenol could be masking fevers
   -          Stop tylenol for 48 hours to trend temperature curve
   -          Continue dilaudid IV for pain
   CAD s/p CABG [**2197**]:  last intervention > 1 year ago, given acute upper
   GI bleed need to stop ASA and Plavix.
   -          Restart imdur when able
   -          Check EKG
   HL: hold atorvastatin and fish oil while NPO
   Vitamin D Deficiency: hold vitamin D
